document.docAuthor: Yang, Linlin, Wang, Shuxia & Li, Houhun
document.docTitle: Edosa varians Yang, Wang & Li, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: A taxonomic revision of the genus Edosa Walker, 1886 from China (Lepidoptera, Tineidae, Perissomasticinae)

Diagnosis. This new species is similar to
E. aurea
sp. nov.
in the male and female genitalia, but can be easily separated by the dusty yellow or yellowish brown forewing, which is glossy golden cream in
E. aurea
sp. nov.
The defining genital feature of the two species is the costal margin of the valva with a triangular or hillock-shaped process bearing finely rugose nodules in
E. varians
sp. nov.
, but with an excurved, ovate flap in
E. aurea
sp. nov.

Pregenital abdomen. First tergum with posterior 2 / 3 sclerotized. In male, coremata present in eighth segment; eighth sternite 0.5× as long as wide, posterior margin gently concave, without caudal process; eighth tergite trapezoidal, without caudal process in male. In female, seventh sternite semicircularly concave at middle on posterior margin.
Distribution. China (Guangdong, Guangxi, Hainan, Hong Kong , Hunan, Yunnan).

Etymology. The specific name is derived from the Latin
varians
, meaning variable, referring to the intraspecific variations of the valva.

Remarks. The valva of this species varies considerably: the apex may be acute (
Fig. 54
c) or blunt (
Fig. 54
d) or being a mastoid process (
Figs 54
a, b); the ventral margin may be either concave at middle (
Figs 54
c, d) or not concave (
Figs 54
a, b); the process on the costal margin may arise from between basal 1 / 4 and middle, large and hillock-shaped (
Fig. 54
b), or from between basal 1 / 3 and middle or just from middle, widened triangularly (
Figs 54
a, c), or from middle, small and triangular (
Fig. 54
d), and it is on the costal margin (
Figs 54
a, c) or slightly intruded into the inner surface of the valva (
Figs 54
b, d).

In some females, the fifth collicular ring is absent, and thus the anterior region of the corpus bursae is not separated into two parts (
Fig. 80
a). The thinly membraneous region is easily missing during dissection.
